  • Method
org.gearvrf.utility

Class Assert

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.utility.Assert

  • public abstract class Assert
extends java.lang.Object
    The goal of this class is to improve the readability and to provide some common checking method to improve the robustness of GVRF. Additionally, this class may help us avoid using GVRJniException, which is (at best) a sort of fake exception-from-JNI.

    Obviously, all parameter checks add runtime cost. Try to use this class sparingly, on user-facing APIs that would otherwise crash: it's probably OK to return meaningless results on meaningless inputs; internal calls should generally rely on careful testing, not parameter checking.

      • checkNotNull

        public static void checkNotNull(java.lang.String parameterName,
                                java.lang.Object object)
        Check that the parameter is not null.
        Parameters:
        parameterName - The name of the user-supplied parameter that we are validating so that the user can easily find the error in their code.
        object - The parameter object can be any Java reference type, including arrays.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the object is null pointer.

      • checkDivisibleDataLength

        public static void checkDivisibleDataLength(java.lang.String parameterName,
                                            int dataLength,
                                            int expectedComponents)
        Check arrays of tuples: is the array length a multiple of the tuple size?
        Parameters:
        parameterName - The name of the user-supplied parameter that we are validating so that the user can easily find the error in their code.
        dataLength - Array parameter length
        expectedComponents - Expected number of components.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the dataLength is zero or not divisible by the expected number.

      • checkFloatNotNaNOrInfinity

        public static void checkFloatNotNaNOrInfinity(java.lang.String parameterName,
                                              float... data)
        In common shader cases, NaN makes little sense. Correspondingly, GVRF is going to use Float.NaN as illegal flag in many cases. Therefore, we need a function to check if there is any setX that is using NaN as input.
        Parameters:
        parameterName - The name of the user-supplied parameter that we are validating so that the user can easily find the error in their code.
        data - A series of input float data.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the data includes NaN.

      • checkFloatNotNaNOrInfinity

        public static void checkFloatNotNaNOrInfinity(java.lang.String parameterName,
                                              float data)
        In common shader cases, NaN makes little sense. Correspondingly, GVRF is going to use Float.NaN as illegal flag in many cases. Therefore, we need a function to check if there is any setX that is using NaN as input.
        Parameters:
        parameterName - The name of the user-supplied parameter that we are validating so that the user can easily find the error in their code.
        data - A single float data.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the data includes NaN.
